summary_points.title: US Tariff Escalation Weighs on Markets
summary_points.summary: Indian equity benchmarks faced renewed pressure as the US government rolled out a draft notification imposing an additional 25% tariff on Indian goods starting Wednesday, effectively lifting total duties on exports to 50%. The heightened trade tension exacerbated investor concerns over India’s export outlook and sparked a sector-wide sell-off, marking the sharpest contraction in Nifty 50 in three months.

summary_points.title: Benchmark Indices Plunge to Fresh Lows
summary_points.summary: Sensex and Nifty50 ended sharply lower, with the Sensex shedding 849.37 points (1.04%) to 80,786.54 and the Nifty declining 255.70 points (1.02%) to 24,712.05. Both indices hit intraday lows—80,685.98 and 24,689.60 respectively—driven by broad-based selling and diminishing risk appetite amid policy uncertainty.

summary_points.title: Midcap and Smallcap Stocks Suffer Heavy Losses
summary_points.summary: Broader-market indices mirrored the decline in the largecaps as the BSE Midcap index fell 1.34% and the Smallcap index dropped 1.68%. The pain extended across smaller stocks, eroding market breadth and underscoring the pervasive bearish sentiment gripping mid- and small-cap segments.

summary_points.title: Foreign Outflows and Global Cues Dampen Sentiment
summary_points.summary: Persistent selling by foreign institutional investors, coupled with weakening cues from Asian markets—where Japan’s Nikkei and South Korea’s Kospi slid over 0.8%—and sell-offs on Wall Street intensified the downturn, compounding the domestic fallout from the tariff action and underscoring the interlinked nature of global equity pressures.

summary_points.title: Investor Wealth Erodes by Trillions
summary_points.summary: The overall market capitalization of BSE-listed companies plunged by approximately ₹4 lakh crore in a single session, falling from ₹449 lakh crore to nearly ₹445 lakh crore, translating to significant erosion in household and institutional wealth amid the sell-off sparked by tariff fears.

summary_points.title: Negative Overnight Signals Point to Risk Aversion
summary_points.summary: Futures markets indicated a cautious start, with Gift Nifty trading around the 24,925 level—a 64-point discount to the previous close—while global benchmarks from Wall Street to Hong Kong pointed lower ahead of key earnings releases and economic data, signaling widespread risk aversion ahead of the domestic trading session.

top_performers.explanation: Technology stocks have remained resilient as investors favor domestic demand–driven software and services less exposed to U.S. tariffs.
Healthcare names have held up on sustained domestic consumption and a defensive earnings profile amid broader market volatility.
NBFCs and banks continue to attract buyers looking for yield and stability, buoyed by strong domestic liquidity and retail participation.

underperformers.explanation: Sectors reliant on overseas sales are under pressure from the new 25% U.S. export tariff, triggering profit‐taking and foreign fund outflows.
Manufacturers exposed to U.S. trade tensions are facing margin headwinds and supply‐chain disruptions, weighing on near-term performance.

market_drivers.summary: Today’s market skid was driven by a confluence of factors: disappointment over Washington’s 25% tariff on Indian imports reignited global trade‐tension angst, while soft earnings from major banks and stretched valuations prompted sector‐specific selling. Foreign institutional outflows intensified the downtrend, offsetting strong domestic liquidity supported by falling interest rates and hopes of GST and broader tax reforms. Meanwhile, weak global cues—from lingering geopolitical uncertainty to murky tariff outcomes—kept investors cautious, making yesterday’s steep fall a story of external shocks, shifting institutional flows, and selective profit‐taking in bank and financial stocks.
